title: MG and Your Eyes

content: Living with myasthenia gravis (MG) means constantly adjusting. Your plans, your expectations, your body. And sometimes, your vision.

Before MG, I never thought much about my eyes. I’ve always been short-sighted, but that was an easy fix. Pop in some contact lenses or throw on a pair of glasses, and I was good to go. It never felt like a limitation or something that got in the way of my life.
MG changed that.

Double vision, or diplopia, is one of the more frustrating symptoms I’ve had. Not just because it makes everyday tasks harder, but because it’s invisible to everyone else. You’re blinking, squinting, tilting your head, closing one eye just to read a menu, and from the outside, you look completely fine.
But from the inside? It’s exhausting.

MG affects your muscles that control your eye movement. When they get weak or fatigued, your eyes stop working together as a team. They start pointing in slightly different directions, which your brain doesn’t know how to process.

content: So it gives you two versions of everything.
Two phones. Two faces. Two roads. And in that moment, even walking in a straight line can feel like a mission.

In my first year after diagnosis, double vision tended to creep in later in the day, when I was tired or overstimulated. It felt like a warning light on the dashboard saying, “You’ve done too much. Slow down.”

Sometimes it was one eye drooping. Sometimes a general fuzziness. And sometimes it was full-on visual chaos, where I physically couldn’t focus unless I shut one eye and took a break. These days, it’s a bit more unpredictable. I can go for weeks with completely normal vision, then suddenly have a full week where it flares up on and off, without much warning.
That’s the thing about MG. You learn to listen to symptoms not just as annoyances, but as messages. They’re your body’s way of speaking. Double vision is often saying: pause now, or pay for it later.

content: And then there are dry eyes. A lovely little side effect of Mestinon. I often find myself stuck between my eyes feeling dry and pressured, or suddenly streaming with tears. Neither option is great, especially when I’ve spent time on makeup.

One minute I’m fine, the next I’ve got mascara halfway down my cheek and can’t see clearly through the watery blur. It might sound minor, but it adds another layer of daily frustration that most people don’t realize comes with this condition.

The practical side of managing it isn’t glamorous. I’ve used eye patches. I’ve worn glasses with a frosted lens or a stick-on film that blocks vision in one eye. Not ideal when you’re trying to look cute, but sometimes fashion has to take a back seat to function.

I've found that keeping lighting soft and reducing screen time helps too, especially during flares. But honestly, the most effective tool is still the most basic one: rest. Closing my eyes. Lying down. Resetting.

content: Of course, not everyone understands what it feels like. When you say, “I can’t really see properly right now,” people look confused. “But you look fine?” Yeah, I know. That’s the frustrating part.

MG is an expert at hiding in plain sight. You can be falling apart internally and still look like you’ve got it together. That disconnect between what you feel and what people see can be isolating. And when your vision, your literal way of seeing the world, starts to betray you, it hits a little deeper.

I used to push through it. I’d ignore the blurring, pretend I could see, act like I was fine because I didn’t want to make a fuss. But that never worked well. I’d end up with a splitting headache, a flare-up, or a wave of shame for pretending I was stronger than I actually felt.

Now, I try to catch it early. If my eyes start to drift, I stop. I check in with myself. And if I need to close one eye, cancel plans, or lie down in a dark room for a bit, I do it. No guilt. No apologies.

content: MG has taught me a lot. One of the biggest lessons is just because something is invisible doesn’t mean it isn’t real. And just because others can’t see your struggle doesn’t mean you have to downplay it.

If you’re navigating life with MG and dealing with double vision, please know you’re not being dramatic. You’re not being difficult. You’re doing your best with something that’s genuinely challenging.

Listen to your eyes. Honour your limits. Adapt how you need to. Whether that means wearing an eye patch, lying down at 3 p.m., or declining that group outing when the lights and noise feel like too much, do what helps.
Protecting your peace sometimes looks like closing one eye and resting the other. And that’s not a weakness. That’s wisdom.
